These relationships were supported by gene expression profiles obtained using bioinformatics analysis. Specifically, the expression of GRM4 and GRM5 showed an increasing trend in RCC tissues, compared to that in normal tissue, whereas GRM3 was downregulated in RCC.

GPCRs, Class C Metabotropic glutamate, pheromone

summary: This gene encodes a member of the G-protein coupled receptor 3 protein family. The encoded protein is a metabatropic glutamate receptor, whose signaling activates a phosphatidylinositol-calcium second messenger system. This protein may be involved in the regulation of neural network activity and synaptic plasticity. Glutamatergic neurotransmission is involved in most aspects of normal brain function and can be perturbed in many neuropathologic conditions. A pseudogene of this gene has been defined on chromosome 11. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants. [provided by RefSeq, May 2014].
